I didn't intend to have this Red Hat change reviewed and approved by only Red Hatters, so downgrading my vote to +1 to reflect that."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-01-24 19:13:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18:

For the record, it's not cool for two cores from the same company to be the sole +2s on a change contributed by the same company. Pretty standard operating procedure. Given the point in the schedule I don't want to pull this out of the gate or anything, but it does have an impact on trust. I see Lee has other changes up related to testing this and those aren't passing, so I'm kind of concerned about why those are failing yet before this was approved.

On another note, is there going to be a release note or documentation for this at all beyond the spec? Like we should at least probably have a release note saying you can do native encrypted volumes with libvirt if you have certain minimums for libvirt/qemu packages, etc etc, and why that's good. The length of the commit message makes me think operators should at least be aware of this non-trivial change."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-01-24 19:29:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18:

> I see Lee has other changes up related to testing this and those
 > aren't passing, so I'm kind of concerned about why those are
 > failing yet before this was approved.

I think this is tested through the existing tempest jobs in most cases and the change Lee has stacked on top of this was to test live migration. I have tried to re-enable volume-backed live migration testing in general [1] in the past and the results are unstable, so failures there are likely because of the instability. I do see runs of legacy-tempest-dsvm-multinode-live-migration that passed for the DNM change [2], but legacy-grenade-dsvm-neutron-multinode-live-migration failed (same as it did in my change [1]).
 
 > On another note, is there going to be a release note or
 > documentation for this at all beyond the spec? Like we should at
 > least probably have a release note saying you can do native
 > encrypted volumes with libvirt if you have certain minimums for
 > libvirt/qemu packages, etc etc, and why that's good. The length of
 > the commit message makes me think operators should at least be
 > aware of this non-trivial change.

Yes, I think that's a good idea and I'll take care of that in a new patch on top of this one.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/528104
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/536350"}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-01-24 19:30:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

Sigh ... messed up the formatting on my other comment:

"I think this is tested through the existing tempest jobs in most cases and the change Lee has stacked on top of this was to test live migration. I have tried to re-enable volume-backed live migration testing in general [1] in the past and the results are unstable, so failures there are likely because of the instability. I do see runs of legacy-tempest-dsvm-multinode-live-migration that passed for the DNM change [2], but legacy-grenade-dsvm-neutron-multinode-live-migration failed (same as it did in my change [1])."'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-01-25 14:21:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

[I particularly don't care about this change.  Just wanted to address the process comment by Matt R.  Although it might not help that I'm also from the same company, but I'm being as objective as I can.]

 > For the record, it's not cool for two cores from the same company
 > to be the sole +2s on a change contributed by the same company.
 > Pretty standard operating procedure.

It *can* be completely cool depending on context.  But a blind rule like
what you state above is not useful.  Why?  It is not ensible, and
implies 'malice'.

I know the history of this topic goes back to this thread from 2014, 
where people were too eager to misunderstand each other:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-August/044550.html
-- "[openstack-dev] [nova] libvirt version_cap, a postmortem"

But hang on for a moment with me here.

We would be better off if _good_ faith is assumed rather than making
people feel like they're always walking on egg shells and are only one
'wrong sneeze' away from being implicated of "collusion" and "trust
erosion".

What _should_ raise a red flag is a _pattern_: Developer-A from Pied
Piper uploads a complex change, within 5 minutes two more upstream "core
reivewers" from Pied Piper, who are in the know about the change, pile
on it and approves (because: "hey, we need to get Pied Piper's priority
feature into the current release to get that one-up against the
competitor!") without giving sufficient time for others to catch-up.  
*That* kind of behaviour should be called out and rebuked.

But as long as a particular change is publicly advertized well-enough,
all necessary information for non-Pied Piper reviewers is described
clearly in the open, respond in every detail that isn't clear to a
community reviewer, gave enough time and heads up for others in the
community to catch up, 2 "core reviewers" from Pied Piper _can_ +W a
change from another contributor from the same comapny.

I.e. be *sensible* and *sincere* when operating with your "upstream 
hat".

[...]'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2018-01-25 14:22:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-01-25 14:41:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

Kashyap, I didn't say there was malice or some kind of conspiracy here. I know Lee has pushed several QA-related patches for this, and has put review updates in the mailing list.

That's not really the point though, at least for me. The issue for me is a slippery slope of, "it was OK that one time, so I suppose it's acceptable now as long as we don't rush things through or try to be sneaky." I don't think anyone was trying to be sneaky here. However, I don't like setting a precedent where it eventually does become an issue, and I, myself, have to feel rushed to review something *before* cores from the same company have a chance to +2/+W it - which I've felt the need to do in the past at times, and it's not fun.

Also, specific to this patch, I did have to ask melwitt to write a release note for it since it was missed here. Once she did, it was noted that this change knowingly regresses swap volume with a luks-encrypted volume. That's not a small detail, IMO. Unless there is a plan to actually fix that before RC1 with some kind of fallback routine if we can detect it, I think it's probably worth holding this up and deferring to Rocky.'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-01-25 17:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

"}, {'created': '2017-12-20 09:36:09.000000000', 'message': 'WIP libvirt: QEMU native LUKS decryption for volumes

QEMU 2.6 and Libvirt 2.2.0 allow LUKS encrypted RAW files, block devices
and network devices (such as rbd) to be decrypted natively by QEMU. This
change enables the use of this feature within the Libvirt virt driver of
Nova when both the `volume_use_native_luks` configurable is enabled and
the appropriate versions of QEMU and Libvirt are installed.

As with the original os-brick encryptors, encrypted volumes that do not
already contain a valid LUKS header will be formatted before use. The
original os-brick LuksEncryptor class is used to format volumes that
present a local block device on the compute host.

As rbd volumes were not supported by these encryptors a separate
codepath is used to format these volumes using qemu-img. At present this
requires that the original volume is removed before being recreated by
qemu-img. Future work should look to avoid the need to recreate the
volume by using QEMU >= 2.10 to convert the image in-place and also
using c-vol to preform this task for all volume backends.

If an encrypted volume does not have a Libvirt secret associated with
it an attempt will still be made to detach LuksEncryptor from the volume.
This will ensure any encrypted volumes connected prior to this change
will still detach the LuksEncryptor correctly during detach or cleanup.

TODO
- Tests
- barbican-tempest-plugin
- swap_volume (?!)
- LM

Depends-On: I404070e2428cdf404b576d1d9da5b917f9be11d1
Implements: blueprint libvirt-qemu-native-luks
Change-Id: Ibfa64f18bbd2fb70db7791330ed1a64fe61c1355
'}, {'created': '2017-12-20 12:22:53.000000000', 'message': 'WIP libvirt: QEMU native LUKS decryption for volumes

this feature within the Libvirt virt driver of Nova when both the

versions of QEMU and Libvirt are installed.

As with the original os-brick encryptors, encrypted volumes that do not
already contain a valid LUKS header will be formatted before use. The
original os-brick LuksEncryptor class is used to format volumes that
present a local block device on the compute host.

If an encrypted volume does not have a Libvirt secret associated with
it an attempt will still be made to detach LuksEncryptor from the volume.
This will ensure any encrypted volumes connected prior to this change
will still detach the LuksEncryptor correctly during detach or cleanup.

Implements: blueprint libvirt-qemu-native-luks
Change-Id: Ibfa64f18bbd2fb70db7791330ed1a64fe61c1355

'}, {'created': '2018-01-15 17:12:31.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: QEMU native LUKS decryption for volumes

QEMU 2.6 and Libvirt 2.2.0 allow LUKS encrypted RAW files, block devices
and network devices (such as rbd) to be decrypted natively by QEMU. This
change enables the use of this feature within Nova when the
`volume_use_native_luks` configurable is enabled, appropriate versions
of QEMU and Libvirt are installed and the encryption provider for the
volume is of type 'luks'.

When these conditions are met a Libvirt secret is created during
_connect_volume to hold the passphrase used to unlock the encrypted
volume. The presences of this Libvirt secret is then used later to
generate the required encryption XML for the disk.

When disconnecting a volume the presence of a Libvirt secret will result
in no attempt being made to detach an os-brick provided encryptor from
the volume. This will only occur when no secret is present, allowing
encrypted volumes attached prior to this change to still be detached
correctly.

Finally, attempts to swap between volumes using native QEMU decryption
will be blocked in the same manor as they are when using volumes that do
not provide a local block device. Both use cases still requiring
additional implementation work in Libvirt before being allowed within
Nova.

Implements: blueprint libvirt-qemu-native-luks
Change-Id: Ibfa64f18bbd2fb70db7791330ed1a64fe61c1355
"}, {'created': '2018-01-16 11:36:49.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: QEMU native LUKS decryption for volumes

Change-Id: Ibfa64f18bbd2fb70db7791330ed1a64fe61c1355
"}, {'created': '2018-01-17 10:28:15.000000000', 'message': "WIP libvirt: QEMU native LUKS decryption for volumes

QEMU 2.6 and Libvirt 2.2.0 allow LUKS encrypted RAW files, block devices
and network devices (such as rbd) to be decrypted natively by QEMU. This
change enables the use of this feature within Nova when the appropriate
versions of QEMU and Libvirt are installed and the encryption provider
for the volume is of type 'luks'.

When these conditions are met a Libvirt secret is created when
connecting encrypted volumes to a compute host to hold the LUKS
passphrase used to unlock the volume. The presences of this Libvirt
secret is then used by the volume driver to generate the required
encryption XML for the disk.

When disconnecting a volume the presence of a Libvirt secret will result
in no attempt being made to detach an os-brick provided encryptor from
the volume. This will only occur when no secret for the volume is found
on the compute host. This will allow encrypted volumes attached prior to
this change to still be detached correctly.

Attempts to swap between volumes while using native QEMU decryption will
be blocked in the same manor as they are when using volumes that do not
provide a local block device. Both use cases still requiring additional
implementation work in Libvirt before being allowed within Nova.

WIP
---

LibvirtLiveMigrateData and LibvirtLiveMigrateBDMInfo are both extended
to help with live migration with encrypted volumes attached.

For Pike to Queens migrations the was_native_luks_available attribute
is added to the LibvirtLiveMigrateData object. This is used to
identify if the source compute was capable of configuring native
LUKS decryption. When Pike is the source host this attribute will be
missing leading to the Queens destination host falling back to the
os-brick encryptors when connecting to the volume during
pre_live_migration.

For Queens to Queens migrations was_native_luks_available will be set to
True assuming the correct QEMU and Libvirt versions are installed on the
source host. The destination will then connect to the encrypted volumes
using the native LUKS approach, creating a Libvirt volume secret. The
UUID of this secret is then stored in the individual
LibvirtLiveMigrateBDMInfo object for the volume and used on the source
while updating the domains XML before starting the migration.

Implements: blueprint libvirt-qemu-native-luks
Change-Id: Ibfa64f18bbd2fb70db7791330ed1a64fe61c1355
"}, {'created': '2018-01-17 15:27:51.000000000', 'message': "WIP libvirt: QEMU native LUKS decryption for volumes

QEMU 2.6 and Libvirt 2.2.0 allow LUKS encrypted RAW files, block devices
and network devices (such as rbd) to be decrypted natively by QEMU. This
change enables the use of this feature within Nova when the appropriate
versions of QEMU and Libvirt are installed and the encryption provider
for the volume is of type 'luks'.

When these conditions are met a Libvirt secret is created when
connecting encrypted volumes to a compute host to hold the LUKS
passphrase used to unlock the volume. The presences of this Libvirt
secret is then used by the volume driver to generate the required
encryption XML for the disk.

When disconnecting a volume the presence of a Libvirt secret will result
in no attempt being made to detach an os-brick provided encryptor from
the volume. This will only occur when no secret for the volume is found
on the compute host. This will allow encrypted volumes attached prior to
this change to still be detached correctly.

Attempts to swap between volumes while using native QEMU decryption will
be blocked in the same manor as they are when using volumes that do not
provide a local block device. Both use cases still requiring additional
implementation work in Libvirt before being allowed within Nova.

LibvirtLiveMigrateData and LibvirtLiveMigrateBDMInfo are both extended
to support the following matrix of live migration (LM) scenarios:

- Pike using os-brick encryptors to Queens using os-brick encryptors
- Queens using os-brick encryptors to Queens using os-brick encryptors
- Queens using os-brick encryptors to Queens using native QEMU decrypt
- Queens using native QEMU decrypt to Queens using native QEMU decrypt

A new 'src_supports_native_luks' attribute has been added to
LibvirtLiveMigrateData in Queens to indicate that the source host is
capable of configuring QEMU LUKS decryption for a volume during LM.

The presence of this attribute in migrate_data during pre_live_migration
on the destination is then used to decide how encrypted volumes are
connected on that host ahead of LM starting.

When missing or False the os-brick encryptors will be attached, when
present and True the native QEMU decryption approach will be taken,
creating a secret on the destination host. The UUID of this secret is
then stored in the individual LibvirtLiveMigrateBDMInfo object
associated with the volume and passed back to the source host to be
added to the volume configuration prior to the start of the live
migration.

Implements: blueprint libvirt-qemu-native-luks
Change-Id: Ibfa64f18bbd2fb70db7791330ed1a64fe61c1355
"}, {'created': '2018-01-19 11:47:34.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: QEMU native LUKS decryption for encrypted volumes

back to the source host to be added to the volume configuration prior to
the start of the live migration.

commit_message:
libvirt: QEMU native LUKS decryption for encrypted volumes

QEMU 2.6 and Libvirt 2.2.0 allow LUKS encrypted RAW files, block devices
and network devices (such as rbd) to be decrypted natively by QEMU. This
change enables the use of this feature within Nova when the appropriate
versions of QEMU and Libvirt are installed and the encryption provider
for the volume is of type 'luks'.

When these conditions are met a Libvirt secret is created when
connecting encrypted volumes to a compute host to hold the LUKS
passphrase used to unlock the volume. The presence of this Libvirt
secret is then used by the volume driver to generate the required
encryption XML for the disk. QEMU is then able to natively read from and
write to the encrypted disk, removing the need for the os-brick supplied
dm-crypt style encryptors, previously used to handle encrypted volumes.

When disconnecting a volume the presence of a Libvirt secret will result
in no attempt being made to detach an os-brick provided encryptor from
the volume. This will only occur when no secret for the volume is found
on the compute host. This will allow encrypted volumes attached prior to
this change to still be detached correctly.

Attempts to swap between volumes while using native QEMU decryption will
be blocked in the same manner as they are when using volumes that do not
provide a local block device. Both use cases still require additional
implementation work in Libvirt before being allowed within Nova.

LibvirtLiveMigrateData and LibvirtLiveMigrateBDMInfo are both extended
to support the following matrix of live migration (LM) scenarios:

- Pike using os-brick encryptors to Queens using os-brick encryptors
- Queens using os-brick encryptors to Queens using os-brick encryptors
- Queens using os-brick encryptors to Queens using native QEMU decrypt
- Queens using native QEMU decrypt to Queens using native QEMU decrypt

A new 'src_supports_native_luks' attribute has been added to
LibvirtLiveMigrateData in Queens to indicate that the source host is
capable of configuring QEMU LUKS decryption for a volume during LM.

The presence of this attribute in migrate_data during pre_live_migration
on the destination is then used to decide how encrypted volumes are
connected on that host ahead of LM starting.

When missing or False the os-brick encryptors will be attached, when
present and True the native QEMU decryption approach will be taken only
if the destination host also supports native LUKS decryption by QEMU.

The UUID of this secret is then stored in the individual
LibvirtLiveMigrateBDMInfo object associated with the volume and passed
back to the source host to be added to the volume configuration prior to
the start of the live migration.

Implements: blueprint libvirt-qemu-native-luks
Change-Id: Ibfa64f18bbd2fb70db7791330ed1a64fe61c1355

commit_message:
Use single quotes in deploy-steps.j2

Use single quotes instead of double quotes in values of key/value pairs
in Ansible tasks in deploy-steps.j2. The use of double quotes can cause
escaping issues later when Ansible is actually run.

Change-Id: I2f652cc9e40e23346fc212f0eb89a2f6b4a29023
Closes-Bug: #1744950

commit_message:
bagpipe-bgp: improve update of export RTs

The current behavior, on an update of export RTs
was to re-originated all recevied routes with the new
export RTs, includings for re-advertised routes for which
the export RTs are not the RTs that should be used
(it should be readvertise/to_rts).  This problem was not
exposed in the use made of readvertisements by BGPVPN
and SFC drivers.

Another issue is that there was a concurrency issue
between VPNInstance reading the list of received routes,
and RouteTableManager populating this list, resulting
in rare occurences of such a traceback:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/opt/stack/new/networking-bagpipe/networking_bagpipe/bagpipe_bgp/api/controllers.py", line 210, in process
    self.manager.plug_vif_to_vpn(**attach_params)
  File "/opt/stack/new/networking-bagpipe/networking_bagpipe/bagpipe_bgp/common/log_decorator.py", line 40, in wrapper
    return method(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/opt/stack/new/networking-bagpipe/networking_bagpipe/bagpipe_bgp/vpn/manager.py", line 338, in plug_vif_to_vpn
    vpn_instance.update_route_targets(import_rts, export_rts)
  File "/opt/stack/new/networking-bagpipe/networking_bagpipe/bagpipe_bgp/common/log_decorator.py", line 40, in wrapper
    return method(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/opt/stack/new/networking-bagpipe/networking_bagpipe/bagpipe_bgp/vpn/vpn_instance.py", line 458, in update_route_targets
    for route_entry in self.get_route_entries():
Set changed size during iteration

Change-Id: Ie55b29f4620c99e9ba3ba1c402ed0f7cf1cc9e98

commit_message:
Use tasks for rhel registration

RHEL registration was implemented using the ExtraConfig interface.
However, this overrides an operator integration point. This can lead to
confusion when using the RHEL registration environment and also trying
to use ExtraConfig for some other configuration. In which case, the last
specified mapping would win, but with no clear indiciation of why the
other was not applied.

Use a custom Task, which by convention, are reserved for internal
TripleO usage for RHEL registration instead of the ExtraConfig
interface.

Change-Id: Idb5189337782583dd8075eeceea4dfa89ad33657
Closes-Bug: 1709441

The virtualenv_support folder missing from the repo
container when upgrading due to the implementation
in the repo_build role which removes it. In order
to prevent breaking the virtualenv tooling, [1] is
being submitted. However, we still need to handle
the situation where the upgrade is done from a
version before that patch is implemented.

This patch implements a force-reinstallation of
virtualenv if the folder is missing.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/540351

commit_message:
If virtualenv is broken, force re-install it

The virtualenv_support folder missing from the repo
container when upgrading due to the implementation
in the repo_build role which removes it. In order
to prevent breaking the virtualenv tooling, [1] is
being submitted. However, we still need to handle
the situation where the upgrade is done from a
version before that patch is implemented.

This patch implements a force-reinstallation of
virtualenv if the folder is missing.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/540351

Change-Id: I2dcfa1abb46ee4e088dac7c9e77e9772ba8a269e
Closes-Bug: #1746935

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-03 14:17:22.000000000', 'message': 'Views accessible via url even if user doesn't match policy rules

When a user doesn't match the policy rules of a panel then the panel tab is removed from the menu of the left, but panel views are still accessible using directly the url (ex /admin/flavors/).

In most of the case, views won't work correctly because of the lack of right in the backend, but it may cause trouble when you play with policies.

I think it could be more elegant to return directly a "You are not authorized to access this page" from the frontend when user try to access a view of a panel (via url) without matching the policy rules.

Change-Id: I7bc93fed29568adfc14d5bcadfc8728d3b5cf633
Closes-Bug: #1741051

commit_message:
Views accessible via url even if user doesn't match policy rules

When a user doesn't match the policy rules of a panel then the panel tab
is removed from the menu of the left, but panel views are still
accessible using directly the url (ex /admin/flavors/).

In most of the case, views won't work correctly because of the lack of
right in the backend, but it may cause trouble when you play with
policies.

I think it could be more elegant to return directly a "You are not
authorized to access this page" from the frontend when user try to
access a view of a panel (via url) without matching the policy rules.

Change-Id: I7bc93fed29568adfc14d5bcadfc8728d3b5cf633
Closes-Bug: #1741051

[{'created': '2018-02-02 13:06:32.000000000', 'message': "Add monasca-transform

Include monasca-transform, the aggregation engine for Monasca.
Also requires Apache Spark to be installed separately.

Specifying a Requires: spark == 1.6.3 seems desirable, but there
is currently no package widely available in the community for
installing that version, so the Requires: is left out to allow an
administrator to manually install from the .tgz or find a suitable
package.
To function properly, Monasca Transform requires a number of Spark
libraries (in .jar format) on the local system.  This install will
not change the versions of these .jar files listed in
/etc/monasca-tranform.conf, so an administrator should reference
the .conf file for names and versions to update.
Note that among those .jar files needed is a JDBC driver for connecting
to a MySQL-compatible database instance.  Drizzle-jdbc 1.3 is expected
and configured in monasca-transform.conf.

Different from other deployments, this .spec inserts an
entry_point into the setup.cfg to allow pbr to create a script,
then installs a .service file that points to the resulting
/usr/bin/monasca-transform script.

Note that the name of the monasca_transform directory in the
.tgz includes an _ and thus doesn't match the sname which
has a -. So instead a variable pypi_tar_name is used.

Note there is a hack for the generic_mysql_jar variable.  Rpmlint
falsely identifies this as needing to be replaced with %{_datadir},
when this is really a match string that needs to match the default
value in monasca-transform.conf.  Hack to get around this is to
concatenate two strings.

Future - need to try moving /etc/monasca-transform.conf

This cherry-pick includes: Updated monasca-transform to 0.11.0

(cherry picked from commit 9bd39e5e0be75383100e7b569cdff8e5f18be1ee)
(cherry picked from commit 3b60d511c3339a64b5fe8ec507797b52a8a5efd0)

Change-Id: Iaa2a5fc7526a19ad58f5199b5eb124caf18dcc45
"}]
commit_message:
Add monasca-transform

Include monasca-transform, the aggregation engine for Monasca.
Also requires Apache Spark to be installed separately.

Specifying a Requires: spark == 1.6.3 seems desirable, but there
is currently no package widely available in the community for
installing that version, so the Requires: is left out to allow an
administrator to manually install from the .tgz or find a suitable
package.
To function properly, Monasca Transform requires a number of Spark
libraries (in .jar format) on the local system.  This install will
not change the versions of these .jar files listed in
/etc/monasca-tranform.conf, so an administrator should reference
the .conf file for names and versions to update.
Note that among those .jar files needed is a JDBC driver for connecting
to a MySQL-compatible database instance.  Drizzle-jdbc 1.3 is expected
and configured in monasca-transform.conf.

Different from other deployments, this .spec inserts an
entry_point into the setup.cfg to allow pbr to create a script,
then installs a .service file that points to the resulting
/usr/bin/monasca-transform script.

Note that the name of the monasca_transform directory in the
.tgz includes an _ and thus doesn't match the sname which
has a -. So instead a variable pypi_tar_name is used.

Note there is a hack for the generic_mysql_jar variable.  Rpmlint
falsely identifies this as needing to be replaced with %{_datadir},
when this is really a match string that needs to match the default
value in monasca-transform.conf.  Hack to get around this is to
concatenate two strings.

Future - need to try moving /etc/monasca-transform.conf

This cherry-pick includes: Updated monasca-transform to 0.11.0

(cherry picked from commit 9bd39e5e0be75383100e7b569cdff8e5f18be1ee)
(cherry picked from commit 3b60d511c3339a64b5fe8ec507797b52a8a5efd0)

Change-Id: Iaa2a5fc7526a19ad58f5199b5eb124caf18dcc45

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-03-28 15:52:32.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Extend datasource to access log data from monasca-log-api.

[Putting this up now as it is done to get some early feedback,
 but obviously can't be used till the API is implemented]

Extend the datasource to be able to return what Grafana refers to as
'doc' objects (essentially JSON) from the monasca-log-api. This will
allow viewing of log entries in Table panels side-by-side with metrics
in Graph or other panels. Due to the way Grafana handles datasource
endpoints, one datasource cannot access multiple endpoints, so two
instances of the plugin must be created. One for metrics, and one for
logs. This change should not break existing installations, and will
assume it's previous behaviour (metrics) unless explicitly configured.

Change-Id: I20249c698d14066abd84fe024b1c1175b2bf234f
Partially-Implements: blueprint log-query-api
Story: 2000934
Task: 4057
"}]
commit_message:
[WIP] Extend datasource to access log data from monasca-log-api.

[Putting this up now as it is done to get some early feedback,
 but obviously can't be used till the API is implemented]

Extend the datasource to be able to return what Grafana refers to as
'doc' objects (essentially JSON) from the monasca-log-api. This will
allow viewing of log entries in Table panels side-by-side with metrics
in Graph or other panels. Due to the way Grafana handles datasource
endpoints, one datasource cannot access multiple endpoints, so two
instances of the plugin must be created. One for metrics, and one for
logs. This change should not break existing installations, and will
assume it's previous behaviour (metrics) unless explicitly configured.

Change-Id: I20249c698d14066abd84fe024b1c1175b2bf234f
Partially-Implements: blueprint log-query-api
Story: 2000934
Task: 4057

[{'created': '2018-02-02 12:20:03.000000000', 'message': '[Trivial] Allow flushing named pipe log handles

The named pipe handler provided by os-win is used by Nova when
consuming instance serial ports. For convenience, it allows logging
the named pipe output to a file (useful for storing the serial
console output).

The issue is that the log file never gets flushed, thus Nova returns
incomplete results. This change adds a method that may be used for
flushing the log file.

Change-Id: I4b5eb7579ac0c92e9c3630539b0c4d76f5b98c6d
Closes-Bug: #1741494
(cherry picked from commit 1b99d30fa2dd83524e87dfc71a8333acb91b2742)
'}]
commit_message:
[Trivial] Allow flushing named pipe log handles

The named pipe handler provided by os-win is used by Nova when
consuming instance serial ports. For convenience, it allows logging
the named pipe output to a file (useful for storing the serial
console output).

The issue is that the log file never gets flushed, thus Nova returns
incomplete results. This change adds a method that may be used for
flushing the log file.

Change-Id: I4b5eb7579ac0c92e9c3630539b0c4d76f5b98c6d
Closes-Bug: #1741494
(cherry picked from commit 1b99d30fa2dd83524e87dfc71a8333acb91b2742)

When updating the MAC spoofing for a given vswitch port, its
Msvm_EthernetSwitchPortSecuritySettingData object is removed
and a new one is created, but the original object is not
cleared from the cache. Because of this, the next update will
fail with a Not Found exception.

This patch addresses this issue.

Closes-Bug: #1744755

Change-Id: I91b9000c64d269b7d5b1db9e0c6344bbd70e37b2

commit_message:
Fixes port security settings caching issue

When updating the MAC spoofing for a given vswitch port, its
Msvm_EthernetSwitchPortSecuritySettingData object is removed
and a new one is created, but the original object is not
cleared from the cache. Because of this, the next update will
fail with a Not Found exception.

This patch addresses this issue.

Closes-Bug: #1744755

Change-Id: I91b9000c64d269b7d5b1db9e0c6344bbd70e37b2
(cherry picked from commit 776270c4b3be0523f2ee2a73792b4a41bb52d6f5)

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 27446, 'date': '2018-02-02 12:30:09.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

[{'created': '2018-01-26 15:46:43.000000000', 'message': 'Allow ability to configure number of processes and threads

The Barbican role currently does not have the ability to set
the number of processes and threads.  This patch adds that feature
with a default value of half the number of cores with a maximum
of 16.

Change-Id: I003ab426488966cce46bd6fd297c79ada13c9668
Closes-Bug: #1745631
'}, {'created': '2018-01-28 17:08:08.000000000', 'message': 'Allow ability to configure number of processes and threads

The Barbican role currently does not have the ability to set
the number of processes and threads.  This patch adds that feature
with a default value of half the number of cores with a maximum
of 16.

Change-Id: I003ab426488966cce46bd6fd297c79ada13c9668
Closes-Bug: #1745631
'}, {'created': '2018-01-28 17:44:54.000000000', 'message': "Allow ability to configure number of processes and threads

Users can configure the number of worker threads however when it's
not specified the calculated number of workers can get too large on
hosts with a large number of CPUs.

This also adds the setting of threads and processes to the UWSGI
configuration.

Change-Id: I003ab426488966cce46bd6fd297c79ada13c9668
Closes-Bug: #1745631
"}]
commit_message:
Allow ability to configure number of processes and threads

Users can configure the number of worker threads however when it's
not specified the calculated number of workers can get too large on
hosts with a large number of CPUs.

This also adds the setting of threads and processes to the UWSGI
configuration.

Change-Id: I003ab426488966cce46bd6fd297c79ada13c9668
Closes-Bug: #1745631

Do these need to be enabled?  I don't see these failing before, so I'm guessing these checks are disabled."}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2018-02-01 02:25:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

diff --git a/tox.ini b/tox.ini

--- a/tox.ini
+++ b/tox.ini
@@ -116,7 +116,7 @@ commands =
 commands = bandit -r octavia -ll -ii -x octavia/tests {posargs}

 [flake8]
-ignore =
+ignore = H104
 show-source = true
 builtins = _
 exclude = .venv,.git,.tox,dist,doc,*lib/python*,*egg,build'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2018-02-01 02:26:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

These pops out when I am trying to disable another error,
Maybe we should explicit disable these errors.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2018-02-02 12:59:50.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I9b2dce8199b279f40a16594bddd8ea3d328c7ef6

commit_message:
roles: bifrost-create-vm-nodes: Set NIC model to 'virtio'

The role already uses the virtio driver to improve the disk peformance.
We can also use the virtio driver for the NIC device in order to improve
the network performance of the test VM. However, users may want to
change that so we are adding a new test_vm_nic Ansible variable for
that.

Change-Id: I9e5c9a33f1f6903d39d0fa2721288d084071e733

commit_message:
tests: autospecs mock.patch and classes usages

By default, mock.patch's autospec argument is None, meaning that
there's no signature checking for the patched methods and funtions.

oslotest.mock_fixture.patch_mock_module fixes a few issues within
mock.patch functions, as well as setting autospec=True by default,
unless otherwise specified or new_callable, create, spec arguments
are passed in.

Updates HyperVBaseTestCase to autospec the classes used by different
*Ops classes.

Change-Id: Ifbdc185d0b50e29c5d5f3ff036141253d2323076
Partial-Bug: #1735588

YES!'}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2018-02-01 15:37:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for looking into this!! Exciting. From what I can tell the VMs do persist after reboot now (yay), I can see and start them with virsh but I can't ssh into the undercloud anymore afterwards:

$ ssh -F ~/.quickstart/ssh.config.ansible undercloud
Warning: Permanently added 'localhost' (ECDSA) to the list of known hosts.
channel 0: open failed: connect failed: Connection refused
stdio forwarding failed
ssh_exchange_identification: Connection closed by remote host

Not sure if I'm applying the environment in the expected way?

$ bash quickstart.sh -T all -R master --no-clone --tags all --nodes config/nodes/1ctlr_1comp.yml  -E config/environments/dev_privileged_virt.yml -p quickstart.yml localhost

I tried a couple of runs and hit the same issue both times (I can only ssh into the undercloud before the reboot). Any thoughts on what I might try to do differently?"}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-02-01 20:19:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-02-02 10:35:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Julie, thanks for testing, possibly I made a mistake as I've been testing this via -c not -E, and I see -E defaults to $OPT_WORKDIR/config/environments/default_libvirt.yml so maybe we should merge that environment with this one?"}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-02-02 12:18:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I pushed https://review.openstack.org/#/c/540350/ which aims to address the comments from Julie.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-01 09:59:22.000000000', 'message': 'Add example of deploying with privileged virt

This example is copied from the following opnfv review

https://gerrit.opnfv.org/gerrit/#/c/28675/26/config/quickstart_defaults.yaml

It seems to work well for me, I can deploy VMs via quickstart which
show up via virt-manager and should survive reboots because
the qcow2 files are stored in /home/stack.

Change-Id: Ifbd0d6eefaebc3e8aec986501e67eadb5d7aa9cd
Closes-Bug: #1692987
'}]
commit_message:
Add example of deploying with privileged virt

This example is copied from the following opnfv review

https://gerrit.opnfv.org/gerrit/#/c/28675/26/config/quickstart_defaults.yaml

It seems to work well for me, I can deploy VMs via quickstart which
show up via virt-manager and should survive reboots because
the qcow2 files are stored in /home/stack.

Change-Id: Ifbd0d6eefaebc3e8aec986501e67eadb5d7aa9cd
Closes-Bug: #1692987

Ability to specify external gateway info for router while creating network context

This patch permit to specify an external gateway info to router while creating
network context instead that is specified in internal.

Change-Id: Icbf2c207fdcb6b288ae81dc7a09fa96898131d59

commit_message:
Handle resources with no name

This commit prevents silent failures when encountering a resource with no name,
which has been observed with glance images that are in a "queued" state.

Change-Id: I65aec02c4e5ac66811006ec7f6ab0c17056ffdb7
Closes-Bug: #1746539

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-29 12:56:04.000000000', 'message': "Vagrantfile: Use rsync to copy working directory to VM

Depending on the VM distro the working directory can either be rsync'd
to the VM or mounted. When the directory is mounted, various artifacts
are left behind from the test execution which is not desired especially
when the directory is shared between multiple VMs for parallel testing.
As such, it's best to simply copy the directory to the VM using 'rsync'
so each VM can get its own copy.

Change-Id: I2ef84692b57e136fc6008f33f3e48f861f9a58da
Link: I1aab7d3f0d26f35dea84ae088fe78cfd2de79366
"}]
commit_message:
Vagrantfile: Use rsync to copy working directory to VM

Depending on the VM distro the working directory can either be rsync'd
to the VM or mounted. When the directory is mounted, various artifacts
are left behind from the test execution which is not desired especially
when the directory is shared between multiple VMs for parallel testing.
As such, it's best to simply copy the directory to the VM using 'rsync'
so each VM can get its own copy.

Change-Id: I2ef84692b57e136fc6008f33f3e48f861f9a58da
Link: I1aab7d3f0d26f35dea84ae088fe78cfd2de79366

[{'created': '2018-01-31 14:41:51.000000000', 'message': 'Add SELinux python support to ansible-runtime venv

This patch adds python bindings for SELinux to the ansible-runtime
venv. It allows ansible to download files and perform other tasks
that require SELinux support (such as downloading the cirros image
during the tempest role run).

A symlink is insufficient based on how the SELinux python module is
structured.

Closes-Bug: 1746283
Change-Id: Ieddf37860f8b84d965d0206e49a0b38f6fc3d2ba
'}]
commit_message:
Add SELinux python support to ansible-runtime venv

This patch adds python bindings for SELinux to the ansible-runtime
venv. It allows ansible to download files and perform other tasks
that require SELinux support (such as downloading the cirros image
during the tempest role run).

A symlink is insufficient based on how the SELinux python module is
structured.

Closes-Bug: 1746283
Change-Id: Ieddf37860f8b84d965d0206e49a0b38f6fc3d2ba

[{'created': '2018-01-12 12:01:15.000000000', 'message': "Set Horizon default member role to 'Member'

As of Ib85479442ec68f9a67615c23e5c39bd217c9b109 Keystone no longer
creates the _member_ role, which Horizon relies on to assign users to
projects. The Member role should still get created as part of a TripleO

commit_message:
Set Horizon default member role to 'Member'

As of Ib85479442ec68f9a67615c23e5c39bd217c9b109 Keystone no longer
creates the _member_ role, which Horizon relies on to assign users to
projects. The Member role should still get created as part of a TripleO
deployment, switch Horizon to using that instead.

Change-Id: Ieebc27a742ebe9f7f68be1f489b142eac13e5b14
Closes-Bug: #1741066

[{'created': '2018-01-24 13:37:58.000000000', 'message': 'Remove build-javascript-tarball job from nodejs-jobs

The sole purpose of the build-javascript-tarball job is to check that
"npm pack" succeeds.  In an npm project, "npm pack" depends on "npm install".
Once the project is successfully installed, "npm pack" always succeeds because
it's just a thin wrapper around "tar".  build-javascript-tarball has nodejs-npm
as its parent which handles installing of npm dependencies.

Therefore, build-javascript-tarball is redundant.

Change-Id: Id57e4c41f23544891f2a16cba3f4b5c59b4610c1
'}, {'created': '2018-01-24 13:38:56.000000000', 'message': 'Remove build-javascript-tarball job from nodejs-jobs

install".  Once the project is successfully installed, "npm pack" always

build-javascript-tarball has nodejs-npm as its parent which handles

Therefore, build-javascript-tarball is redundant.

Change-Id: Id57e4c41f23544891f2a16cba3f4b5c59b4610c1
'}]
commit_message:
Remove build-javascript-tarball job from nodejs-jobs

The sole purpose of the build-javascript-tarball job is to check that
"npm pack" succeeds.  In an npm project, "npm pack" depends on "npm
install".  Once the project is successfully installed, "npm pack" always
succeeds because it's just a thin wrapper around "tar".
build-javascript-tarball has nodejs-npm as its parent which handles
installing of npm dependencies.

Therefore, build-javascript-tarball is redundant.

Change-Id: Id57e4c41f23544891f2a16cba3f4b5c59b4610c1

commit_message:
Fix vmware-nsx stable-periodic docs job

The vmware-nsx job has been failing with an error looking for
the networking-l2gw repo. Turns out there are several repos
needed by this job, but the stable-periodic pipeline did not
define the required-projects that were used elsewhere.

This adds the required-projects used in the check and check
and gate queues to the job in the periodic-stable pipeline.

Change-Id: I29a7dd501ec9878b7b9bd14f1bd2db957e78e142

[{'created': '2017-10-19 10:09:48.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Add validation task in docker services [Ceilometer]

Docker services are missing the pre-upgrade validation task
in the upgrade_tasks section which verifies if the service
is running before going on with the upgrade.

Also, remove 'when' condition to stop and disable the
service as this is an idempotent operation. This way
we ensure the service is always stopped and disabled.

commit_message:
Add validation task in docker services [Ceilometer]

Docker services are missing the pre-upgrade validation task
in the upgrade_tasks section which verifies if the service
is running before going on with the upgrade.

(cherry picked from 776338d54c030c3a9a02fc0e76ad27f35342fba2)
Change-Id: I28488b51e6a2e2d0e0ac41d0d7c35be4edb59cbb
Partial-Bug: #1704389
Closes-Bug: #1724478

[{'created': '2018-01-31 15:56:27.000000000', 'message': 'Improve console install and restart services appropriately

The current implementation wipes out the novnc/spice directory
every single time the playbook executes. While it does replace
it afterwards it does not fire a notifier to make the service
restart, resulting in the service failing.

This patch makes the install process idempotent - it will only
wipe out the directory if it does not look the way it is
expected to look. It also fires the notifier to restart services
if the git repo changes.

This should ensure that novnc/spice restart properly on upgrades
and that there are no changes/restarts for the service if the git
SHA or software does not change.

Closes-Bug: #1746523
Change-Id: Ic39f884016a6ba0498110267027783001a087a1c
'}, {'created': '2018-02-01 12:51:54.000000000', 'message': 'Improve console install and restart services appropriately

The current implementation wipes out the novnc/spice directory
every single time the playbook executes. While it does replace

restart, resulting in the service failing.

This patch makes the install process idempotent - it will only
wipe out the directory if it does not look the way it is
expected to look. It also fires the notifier to restart services
if the git repo changes.

This should ensure that novnc/spice restart properly on upgrades
and that there are no changes/restarts for the service if the git
SHA or software does not change.

Closes-Bug: #1746523
Change-Id: Ic39f884016a6ba0498110267027783001a087a1c
'}]
commit_message:
Improve console install and restart services appropriately

The current implementation wipes out the novnc/spice directory
every single time the playbook executes. While it does replace
it afterwards it does not fire a notifier to make the service
restart, resulting in the service failing.

This patch makes the install process idempotent - it will only
wipe out the directory if it does not look the way it is
expected to look. It also fires the notifier to restart services
if the git repo changes.

This should ensure that novnc/spice restart properly on upgrades
and that there are no changes/restarts for the service if the git
SHA or software does not change.

Closes-Bug: #1746523
Change-Id: Ic39f884016a6ba0498110267027783001a087a1c

[{'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2018-01-16 00:04:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2018-01-16 00:07:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-01-16 08:46:35.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bp/s to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-01-16 19:53:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

Project appears to be following our community processes and provides functionality not currently covered.

A little concerned about lack of diversity on the project, and seeing things like self approving patches with no other reviewers (and including multiple different things in one review) [1], but I think for where the project is, that can hopefully be something that changes as it grows.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/532363/'}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2018-01-16 20:50:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> A little concerned about lack of diversity on the project, and
 > seeing things like self approving patches with no other reviewers
 > (and including multiple different things in one review) [1], but I
 > think for where the project is, that can hopefully be something
 > that changes as it grows.
 
Thanks Sean, I believe the situation will change when there are more active contributors and more collaborations.'}, {'account_id': 9796, 'date': '2018-01-17 10:50:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-01-17 15:25:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

I'm a fan of Qinling and in the absence of some other good home I think we should accept it. It is both a useful and exciting project in the OpenStack ecosystem.

However, as discussed in IRC, this _may_ be an opportunity to narrow the focus of projects which are accepted into governance. Since Qinling relies on containers it could be argued that it should go in the same box that Kata is in. But that group may not be mature enough.

I agree with other comments that diversity is an issue now, but would expect to see that improve over time.

I'll hold off on a rollcall vote for now until we have a more clear picture of the overall foundation ecosystem. The code-review +1 is a "yeah I like this".'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-01-17 15:25:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1 Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

"Serverless" is just another way to consume cloud infrastructure. While it is not a model that applies to everything, it has its uses/users, and Qinling therefore fills a gap in "OpenStack".

On the infrastructure side, Serverless relies on deep integration with the specific other services provided by the same cloud (which is why AWS Lambda is seen by many as a lock-in trap: you can't replicate it elsewhere and your applications are trapped there). To provide a similar experience (but portable accross OpenStack clouds) we need an openstack-native solution that deeply integrates with other OpenStack services.

So I think Qinling is on the right track. I'm not worried that it has not attracted diverse contributions yet, I expect that to come with the increased visibility once it becomes an official OpenStack project.

Two caveats:

- Qinling won't be added for Queens, we'd likely approve it at the start of Rocky. If you wanted to attend the PTG in Dublin, we can arrange something :)

- See comments inline related to the mission wording.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-01-17 16:30:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2018-01-17 21:20:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2018-01-17 21:21:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Majority reached, to be approved on Friday if no new objection is posted.'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2018-01-23 21:19:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1607, 'date': '2018-01-23 22:58:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6062, 'date': '2018-01-25 05:55:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-01-25 21:25:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

> Since Qinling relies on containers it could be argued that it should go in the same box that Kata is in.

I guess, but it'd be an incredibly weak argument. ("mumble mumble containers mumble mumble"?) We're talking about an OpenStack-style service with an OpenStack-style API that integrates with other OpenStack services - just like e.g. Magnum or Zun, which also involve containers (although Mistral is the one it's most similar to). Kata is (conceptually speaking) sort-of like a libvirt for containers. There's absolutely no comparison there. This isn't remotely a grey area.

> On the infrastructure side, Serverless relies on deep integration with the specific other services provided by the same cloud (which is why AWS Lambda is seen by many as a lock-in trap: you can't replicate it elsewhere and your applications are trapped there). To provide a similar experience (but portable accross OpenStack clouds) we need an openstack-native solution that deeply integrates with other OpenStack services.

I couldn't have put it better myself :)

BTW I would hesitate to use the term "serverless" here. In my mind (and possibly only there) I associate "serverless" with the concept of running the application code entirely from a FaaS. So in AWS it's Lambda *plus* API Gateway (plus all the other services like e.g. S3, DynamoDB, SQS that your code can use), and there are a lot of difficult technical requirements like maintaining very low latency without chewing up resources when it's not being used - otherwise it's basically just a PaaS.

My guess is that if you want to hop on the serverless train then you probably want to make use of an open source serverless framework. That means you'll want to be using, if not AWS/Azure/Google, a well-established FaaS provider such as OpenWhisk. And IIUC Qinling hasn't yet really attempted to tackle that use case.

That's not to say that FaaS isn't a useful thing outside of serverless use cases. It's super useful to be able to write your own glue between cloud services in a language of your choice and have it run in the cloud in response to events (if only we could get notified about those...). And of course this needs to be tightly integrated with the cloud. Basically like Mistral, except you're not constrained to writing code in yaql. (The existence of Storlets is testament to the usefulness of this. It would be so much better if we had something like that that wasn't limited to only consuming events from Swift and instead integrated with the whole of OpenStack, and that's what Qinling is trying to do.)

So I am definitely +1 on this, but don't be surprised if this is not the last FaaS project that gets proposed to OpenStack. I wouldn't be at all shocked if there were also folks out there who were interested in trying to integrate something like OpenWhisk with OpenStack for doing true 'serverless' stuff. The holy grail for FaaS would be tightly integrated with OpenStack, widely popular outside of OpenStack, with an integrated API gateway and the other requirements for serverless; since that won't happen any time soon we may well end up with multiple solutions.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-01-26 15:29:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> That's not to say that FaaS isn't a useful thing outside of
 > serverless use cases. It's super useful to be able to write your
 > own glue between cloud services in a language of your choice and
 > have it run in the cloud in response to events (if only we could
 > get notified about those...). And of course this needs to be
 > tightly integrated with the cloud. Basically like Mistral, except
 > you're not constrained to writing code in yaql. (The existence of
 > Storlets is testament to the usefulness of this. It would be so
 > much better if we had something like that that wasn't limited to
 > only consuming events from Swift and instead integrated with the
 > whole of OpenStack, and that's what Qinling is trying to do.)
 > 
 > So I am definitely +1 on this, but don't be surprised if this is
 > not the last FaaS project that gets proposed to OpenStack. I
 > wouldn't be at all shocked if there were also folks out there who
 > were interested in trying to integrate something like OpenWhisk
 > with OpenStack for doing true 'serverless' stuff. The holy grail
 > for FaaS would be tightly integrated with OpenStack, widely popular
 > outside of OpenStack, with an integrated API gateway and the other
 > requirements for serverless; since that won't happen any time soon
 > we may well end up with multiple solutions.

These are really good points. I've already voted +1 but was still considering this issue myself. I wonder why the Qinling folks built their own thing instead of doing that integration work with another project like OpenWhisk. Was there some technical limitation that made building it from scratch easier?"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-01-26 15:32:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I think this is an interesting discussion to have (and we are not in a hurry since this is a Rocky addition anyway), so let's drag a bit more before pushing the Workflow+1 button."}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2018-01-27 11:30:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

As I mentioned in the commit message, before we implementing Qinling, we already took a look at the existing solutions that can be integrated with OpenStack, including Picasso, OpenWhisk, and a couple of projects in the k8s ecosystem. There are several reasons that we want to implement a separate 'OpenStack' thing:

- The closest project can satisfy our requirement is Picasso[1], it provides OpenStack API, has its authentication with Keystone. However, that project relies on another open source project(IronFunctions) controlled by one company(actually Picasso itself is contributed by that one company). What's more, the code style, library usage, CI are far more behind openstack upstream, and it has nothing to do with any other openstack services, no one answered my question in IRC channel, etc. It will be very difficult for us to build our own solution based on it as soon as possible. BTW, the project has no commit since Mar 2017. 
- Creating a project that integrates OpenWhisk is no difference with Picasso. OpenWhisk is one of the most famous open source FaaS project that driven by IBM and Adobe, but unfortunately, it's written in Scala, almost no one in our company is familiar with the programming language(I'm not sure how many people in OpenStack community are interested in it), and it's using Kafka, CouchDB, consul components that are not commonly adopted by OpenStack community. The cost of maintaining such a proxy project will be quite high.
- So, why Qinling? We need a project that can be developed and evolved with the whole OpenStack community as part of the OpenStack ecosystem, and tightly integrated with other OpenStack services, can be deployed like other OpenStack services. The users are allowed to store functions in Swift, can subscribe functions in Zaqar message queue, can conveniently talk to other OpenStack services in their own functions, can access to their own Neutron network, the function execution metrics can be stored in Ceilometer/Gnocchi, function can be invoked by Aodh event alarm, etc. During the implementation of Qinling, we realized that there are already a lot of options out there providing FaaS stuff, so we are using pluggable architecture and some components of Qinling can be easily replaced. For example, you can definitely integrate OpenWhisk or other FaaS projects out of OpenStack into Qinling by only retaining qinling-api at your own convenience (although I personally don't think it will make much sense to most of OpenStack based cloud providers like us).

So, I'm not saying Qinling is not the first FaaS project in OpenStack, neither the last one. We want an OpenStack FaaS project deployed in our production and also want to provide an option to the OpenStack community, we are open for any kind of collaboration and cooperation.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/picasso"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-01-27 16:22:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thank you for the extra detail. The differences in underlying technologies, and the integration with other OpenStack services, are reasonable arguments in favor of providing a new implementation.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-01-31 15:35:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

For reference http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/%23openstack-tc.2018-01-29.log.html#t2018-01-29T17:25:25 has some discussion on why incepting projects makes more sense in openstack than it might other places'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-02-02 09:43:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1

OK, time to approve, after waiting an additional week.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-16 00:04:46.000000000', 'message': 'Qinling: Function as a Service in OpenStack

Qinling aims to provide "Function as a service" in OpenStack. Qinling provide a
platform to support serverless functions (like AWS Lambda) by leveraging the
container orchestration platforms (Kubernetes/Swarm, etc.) and different
function package storage backends (local/Swift/S3) using plugable mechanism.

Project History:
As an OpenStack based public cloud provider in New Zealand,
Catalyst Cloud[1] helps most of local enterprise customers to innovate by using
and contributing lots of OpenStack projects. From the feedback and requirements
of our customers, FaaS is one of the most wanted services. After evaluating the
existing open source projects, we decided to create a new project in OpenStack
and started development from the April of 2017. We also did several successful
POCs during 2017 after the first alpha release. In Sydney Summit, the project
was first introduced to the whole community[2].

Because most of the engineers from Catalyst Cloud development team are active
and experienced contributors in OpenStack upstream, the project developement
process aligns with the OpenStack upstream convention from day 1. What's more,
as an OpenStack project, we are trying to integrate with other OpenStack
services as possible as we could, e.g. Qinling uses keystonemiddleware for
authentication; supports functions to be stored in Swift; in the function code,
the developers can easily interact with other services without explicitly
providing and storing their own OpenStack credentials; Qinling supports webhook
URL for functions that can be used direclty in Aodh or Zaqar, etc. Most
importantly, Qinling doesn't rely on any commercial product for its
implementation.

Satisfaction of new projects requirements:

* Open Source: All Qinling source codes, specifications, and
  documentations are use Apache License 2.0. All the library dependencies
  come from the global requirements file of openstack/requirements repo.

* Open Community: I myself am current PTL of the project and will continue
  working on it almost full time. Although we don't have weekly irc meeting
  yet, #openstack-qinling IRC channel is always open for anyone to interact
  with Qinling team. I keep sending the project update email by-weekly in
  openstack-dev mailing list[3][4]. After the Qinling presentation in Sydney
  Summit, there are more and more developers showing interests to the project
  by contribution[5].

* Open Development: Qinling uses Gerrit for code reviews and Launchpad
  for bugs and blueprints tracking[6]. The project is integrated with the
  Openstack CI, and runs pep8, py27 and functional jobs. Qinling is implemented
  using libraries and technologies adopted by other existing OpenStack projects.

* Open Design: Currently, all the features and bugs can be found in Launchpad,
  any feature requests are welcomed. As I mentioned, we also use openstack-dev
  mailing list for discussion about anything related to the project.

The Qinling team is happy to participate in any goals specified by TC, and meet
any other policies that the TC requires.

[1]: https://www.catalyst.net.nz/catalyst-cloud
[2]: https://youtu.be/NmCmOfRBlIU
[3]: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-December/125413.html
[4]: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-January/126018.html
[5]: http://stackalytics.com/?project_type=openstack-others&metric=commits&release=all&module=qinling

Change-Id: I5fe1ff0067d4df12b2d05da0f7bc723da24e5975

commit_message:
Qinling: Function as a Service in OpenStack

Qinling aims to provide "Function as a service" in OpenStack. Qinling provides
a platform to support serverless functions (like AWS Lambda) by leveraging the
container orchestration platforms (Kubernetes/Swarm, etc.) and different
function package storage backends (local/Swift/S3) using plugable mechanism.

Project History:
As an OpenStack based public cloud provider in New Zealand,
Catalyst Cloud[1] helps most of local enterprise customers to innovate by using
and contributing lots of OpenStack projects. From the feedback and requirements
of our customers, FaaS is one of the most wanted services. After evaluating the
existing open source projects, we decided to create a new project in OpenStack
and started development from the April of 2017. We also did several successful
POCs during 2017 after the first alpha release. In Sydney Summit, the project
was first introduced to the whole community[2].

As most of the engineers from Catalyst Cloud development team are active
and experienced contributors in OpenStack upstream, the project developement
process aligns with the OpenStack upstream convention from day 1. What's more,
as an OpenStack project, we are trying to integrate with other OpenStack
services as possible as we could, e.g. Qinling uses keystonemiddleware for
authentication; supports functions to be stored in Swift; in the function code,
the developers can easily interact with other services without explicitly
providing and storing their own OpenStack credentials; Qinling supports webhook
URL for functions that can be used direclty in Aodh or Zaqar, etc. Most
importantly, Qinling doesn't rely on any commercial product for its
implementation.

Satisfaction of new projects requirements:

* Open Source: All Qinling source codes, specifications, and
  documentations are use Apache License 2.0. All the library dependencies
  come from the global requirements file of openstack/requirements repo.

* Open Community: I myself am current PTL of the project and will continue
  working on it almost full time. Although we don't have weekly irc meeting
  yet, #openstack-qinling IRC channel is always open for anyone to interact
  with Qinling team. I keep sending the project update email by-weekly in
  openstack-dev mailing list[3][4]. After the Qinling presentation in Sydney
  Summit, there are more and more developers showing interests to the project
  by contribution[5].

* Open Development: Qinling uses Gerrit for code reviews and Launchpad
  for bugs and blueprints tracking[6]. The project is integrated with the
  Openstack CI, and runs pep8, py27 and functional jobs. Qinling is implemented
  using libraries and technologies adopted by other existing OpenStack projects.

* Open Design: Currently, all the features and bugs can be found in Launchpad,
  any feature requests are welcomed. As I mentioned, we also use openstack-dev
  mailing list for discussion about anything related to the project.

The Qinling team is happy to participate in any goals specified by TC, and meet
any other policies that the TC requires.

[1]: https://www.catalyst.net.nz/catalyst-cloud
[2]: https://youtu.be/NmCmOfRBlIU
[3]: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-December/125413.html
[4]: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-January/126018.html
[5]: http://stackalytics.com/?project_type=openstack-others&metric=commits&release=all&module=qinling

Change-Id: I5fe1ff0067d4df12b2d05da0f7bc723da24e5975

commit_message:
doc: placement upgrade notes for queens

This adds a mention of the nova-scheduler service requiring
placement 1.17 and also links to the placement upgrade notes
from the more general upgrade notes, since we are now firmly
in a place where placement needs to be upgraded before nova.

Since we consider placement global, this removes the 1.14
note about nova-compute since we assume that if you're going
to upgrade placement to get 1.17 for the scheduler, and control
services should be upgraded before computes, then the computes
are going to get a new enough placement service automatically.

Change-Id: I06937c7642dca4a1932cbbf46569acc9c58e44a6

[{'created': '2017-09-30 01:25:13.000000000', 'message': "Stop _undefine_domain erroring if domain not found

During live-migration stress testing we are seeing the following log:
Error from libvirt during undefine. Code=42 Error=Domain not found

There appears to be a race while trying to undefine the domain, and
something else is possibly also doing some kind of clean up. While this
does paper over that race, it stops otherwise completed live-migrations
from failing. It also matches similar error handling done for when
deleting the domain.

The next part of the bug fix is to ensure if we have any similar
unexpected errors during this later phase of the live-migration we don't
leave the instance stuck in the migrating state, it should move to an
ERROR state. This is covered in a follow on patch.

Partial-Bug: #1662626

Change-Id: I23ed9819061bfa436b12180110666c5b8c3e0f70

commit_message:
Stop _undefine_domain erroring if domain not found

During live-migration stress testing we are seeing the following log:
Error from libvirt during undefine. Code=42 Error=Domain not found

There appears to be a race while trying to undefine the domain, and
something else is possibly also doing some kind of clean up. While this
does paper over that race, it stops otherwise completed live-migrations
from failing. It also matches similar error handling done for when
deleting the domain.

The next part of the bug fix is to ensure if we have any similar
unexpected errors during this later phase of the live-migration we don't
leave the instance stuck in the migrating state, it should move to an
ERROR state. This is covered in a follow on patch.

Partial-Bug: #1662626

Change-Id: I23ed9819061bfa436b12180110666c5b8c3e0f70
(cherry picked from commit b706155888d740841d745c52aae543cf82fab0bc)

commit_message:
use . instead of source.

Code conventions: Use â.â to source script files
When you have to source a script file, for example ,
a credentials file to gain access to user-only or
 admin-only CLI commands, use . instead of source.
See more:
http://docs.openstack.org/contributor-guide/writing-style/code-conventions

Change-Id: If2ef1f3f56008f7e9e1bec13b94d542a3b9667e7

In some cases software deliberately allows drop-in config file usage
capabilities, for example, when it comes to enforcing policy, the

primary charm to render.

Given that properties and desired adapters can be arbitrary the change
uses a dict of meta tuples of the following format to render templates
from strings based on adapter properties:

commit_message:
add string template rendering capability

In some cases software deliberately allows drop-in config file usage
capabilities, for example, when it comes to enforcing policy, the
desired behavior varies from an operator to operator. For that reason it
is sometimes desirable to supply custom templates via config options.

Another use-case is templates that are passed from subordinates for a
primary charm to render.

Given that properties and desired adapters can be arbitrary the change
uses a dict of meta tuples of the following format to render templates
from strings based on adapter properties:

{config_file_path: (relation_name, adapter property)}

relation names must be normalized (lowercase, underscores instead of
dashes. "options" relation name is used for a config adapter as usual.

In summary a string config file path should be used:

1. in the restart_map for a given derived class;
2. in string_templates dict as a key for a meta tuple

Change-Id: Ic85b22d0e5d497c49c75243e3c280140f940df66
Closes-Bug: #1741723

commit_message:
Remove project name from Zuul

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I68c3d7c1856bc6e347f0368024ec54df38e6e74c

commit_message:
Wait for ironic-neutron-agent to report state

Wait for the agent to finish reporting state, bridge_mappings
must be reported prior to any cleaning attempts.

Change-Id: I041761dd896c9d89dc6cf7bafc991a0697ded05b
Related-Bug: #1658964

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I1877f6f2f79bfec69a45f140c8a12c43de5421ef

commit_message:
Remove unwanted test packages from puppet-tempest

* python-{swift,nova,glance}-tests contains only unit tests.
  It does not make any sense to install it. As it does not have
  tempest tests. Their tempest tests resides with in tempest
  package itself.

Change-Id: I17afca9a98b0920c6b6ecb0e82a7d80198d1f810

commit_message:
Move zuulv3 jobs to project repo

This patch moves the zuulv3 jobs for ec2-api repo.

This is first step to switch jobs to ec2 tempest plugin.

There is already gate broken due to switching neutron_vpnaas
to neutron-tempest-plugin whichy stop any further updates to merge
in ec2-api repo.
This commit also fix that.

To make this merge, legacy job needs to be remopved first. Done in below
dependent patch:

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Ibfc90dc9425f244272ca566561bf814519bf39dc

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

commit_message:
Use single quotes instead of backquotes for i18n string

Using the backquotes causes the new lines to appear as is in the pot
files, making the pot file invalid and causing the upload to Zanata to
fail with the "missing end-quote" error.

Change-Id: I820cac7ad401bd0e0c0e31f088c4efede3263ff2
Closes-Bug: #1737577
(cherry picked from commit c18a9b9819b77e3f9bdccc3ec2fef6a103d75cf1)

- nova-dsvm-full-tempest http://cloudbase-ci.com//nova/531517/1/ : FAILURE in 1h 25m 16s'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-01-08 14:22:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Interesting. Acknowledging that this is a WIP and everything, take the following with salt:

This will certainly be an improvement, but I had assumed that we would be setting limit to some multiple of the number of hosts requested, modified by "something" to account for retries, filter noise, etc.

If someone wants to place one host, asking for up to 1000 seems overkill. Since we're already going to limiting by some resource classes and traits, can we make it smaller.

Maybe configure the multiplier?'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-01-11 15:46:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

> Interesting. Acknowledging that this is a WIP and everything, take
 > the following with salt:
 > 
 > This will certainly be an improvement, but I had assumed that we
 > would be setting limit to some multiple of the number of hosts
 > requested, modified by "something" to account for retries, filter
 > noise, etc.
 > 
 > If someone wants to place one host, asking for up to 1000 seems
 > overkill. Since we're already going to limiting by some resource
 > classes and traits, can we make it smaller.
 > 
 > Maybe configure the multiplier?

I'm not opposed to that. I wonder if that will be more complicated and/or need to scale differently through the range. It also kinda needs an upper limit to prevent DoS attacts for unexpectedly-large boot requests. If I set this to 20 thinking about one or two instances, but someone boots a hundred, then this jumps up a lot quickly.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-01-11 18:08:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2018-01-11 19:38:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Pass limit to /allocation_requests

This makes us pass an upper limit to placement when doing scheduling
activities. Without this, we'll always receive every host in the
deployment (that has space for the request), which may be very large.

Closes-Bug: #1746294
Change-Id: I1c34964a74123b3d94ccae89d7cac0426b57b9b6

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-17 17:07:21.000000000', 'message': 'handle no default_cgsnapshot_type

If default_cgsnapshot_type has been deleted, group operations for
drivers relying on the generic volume group implementation were failing
with a KeyError while attempting to determine if the targeted group was
default_cgsnapshot_type. This fixes that by using a comparison that
allows for the possibility that default_cgsnapshot_type does not
exist.

Change-Id: Ic220ea4d8a6e83293e5237acfb07b1a417293803
Closes-Bug: #1710937
(cherry picked from commit be7b476d562f79d649724555aeadfad60127e356)
'}]
commit_message:
handle no default_cgsnapshot_type

If default_cgsnapshot_type has been deleted, group operations for
drivers relying on the generic volume group implementation were failing
with a KeyError while attempting to determine if the targeted group was
default_cgsnapshot_type. This fixes that by using a comparison that
allows for the possibility that default_cgsnapshot_type does not
exist.

Change-Id: Ic220ea4d8a6e83293e5237acfb07b1a417293803
Closes-Bug: #1710937
(cherry picked from commit be7b476d562f79d649724555aeadfad60127e356)
